qas.question: An anglicization of the name Osman I results in what word?
What house was the founder of the Ottoman empire?
What was another name for the Ottoman Dynasty?
What is the origin of Osman's name?
In a literal sense what was the Ottoman empire referred to as?

answers.text: The Supreme State of the Ottomans

context: The word <a0_0>Ottoman<a0_0/> is a historical anglicisation of the name of Osman I, the founder of the Empire and of the ruling <a1_0><a2_0>House of Osman<a2_0/><a1_0/> (also known as the Ottoman dynasty). Osman's name in turn was derived from the Persian form of the name ʿUthmān عثمان of ultimately <a3_0>Arabic<a3_0/> origin. In Ottoman Turkish, the empire was referred to as Devlet-i ʿAliyye-yi ʿOsmâniyye (دَوْلَتِ عَلِيّهٔ عُثمَانِیّه), (literally "<a4_0>The Supreme State of the Ottomans<a4_0/>") or alternatively Osmanlı Devleti (عثمانلى دولتى).[dn 5] In Modern Turkish, it is known as Osmanlı İmparatorluğu ("Ottoman Empire") or Osmanlı Devleti ("The Ottoman State").
